study.name: M14-031
study.officialTitle: A Phase 3, Multicenter, Randomized, Double Blind Study of Bortezomib and Dexamethasone in Combination with Either Venetoclax or Placebo in Subjects with Relapsed or Refractory Multiple Myeloma Who are Sensitive or Naïve to Proteasome Inhibitors

provenance.text_snippet:
Clinical Study Protocol M14-031

A Phase 3, Multicenter, Randomized, Double Blind 
Study of Bortezomib and Dexamethasone in 
Combination with Either Venetoclax or Placebo in 
Subjects with Relapsed or Refractory Multiple 
Myeloma Who are Sensitive or Naïve to Proteasome 
Inhibitors

A Phase 3, Multicenter, Randomized, Double Blind 
Study of Bortezomib and Dexamethasone in 
Combination with Either Venetoclax or Placebo in 
Subjects with Relapsed or Refractory Multiple 
Myeloma Who are Sensitive or Naïve to Proteasome 
Inhibitors

Methodology: 
This is a Phase 3, multicenter, randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled, parallel group study. This 
study is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of venetoclax plus bortezomib and dexamethasone 
(Bd) in subjects with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who are considered sensitive or naïve to 
proteasome inhibitors and have received 1 to 3 prior lines of therapy for multiple myeloma.

Study Population: Adult male and female subjects with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who are considered sensitive or naïve to proteasome inhibitors, have received 1 to 3 prior lines of therapy for multiple myeloma, and have measurable disease per International Myeloma Working Group (IMWG) criteria.

Study Population: Adult male and female subjects with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who are considered sensitive or naïve to proteasome inhibitors, have received 1 to 3 prior lines of therapy for multiple myeloma, and have measurable disease per International Myeloma Working Group (IMWG) criteria.
1. Eastern Collaborative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance score of ≤ 2.

values: Eastern Collaborative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance score of ≤ 2.
Documented relapsed or progressive multiple myeloma on or after any regimen or is refractory to the most recent line of therapy.
Received at least one, but no more than three, prior lines of therapy for multiple myeloma.

Prior treatment with bortezomib or other proteasome inhibitor is allowed, provided disease is NOT refractory, best response was at least a Partial Response (PR), and subject did not discontinue due to intolerance or ≥ Grade 3 related toxicity.

Measurable disease at Screening, defined as Serum M-protein ≥ 0.5 g/dL, OR Urine M-protein ≥ 200 mg in 24 hours, OR Serum immunoglobulin free light chain (FLC) ≥ 10 mg/dL provided serum FLC ratio is abnormal.

provenance.text_snippet:
Main Inclusion:
1. Eastern Collaborative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance score of ≤ 2.
2. Subjects has documented relapsed or progressive multiple myeloma on or after any regimen or is refractory to the most recent line of therapy.
3. Subject must have received prior treatment with at least one, but no more than three, prior lines of therapy for multiple myeloma.
4. Prior treatment with bortezomib or other proteasome inhibitor is allowed, provided: ALL of the following criteria are met:
5.

values: Subject is refractory to any proteasome inhibitor.
Subject has had prior treatment with proteasome inhibitor within 60 days prior to first dose of study drug.
Subject has non-secretory multiple myeloma, active plasma cell leukemia, Waldenström's macroglobulinemia, Amyloidosis, or POEMS syndrome.
Significant cardiovascular disease, including uncontrolled angina, hypertension, arrhythmia, recent myocardial infarction within 6 months, or congestive heart failure NYHA Class ≥ 3.
History of other active malignancies, including myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), within the past 3 years prior to study entry, with specified exceptions.
If subject had prior stem cell transplant (SCT), subject has evidence of ongoing graft-versus-host disease (GvHD).

provenance.text_snippet:
Main Exclusion:
1. Subject is refractory to any proteasome inhibitor, defined as progression on or within 60 days of the last dose of a proteasome inhibitor-containing regimen.
2. Subject has had prior treatment with proteasome inhibitor within 60 days prior to first dose of study drug.
3. Subject has any of the following conditions:
4.

Study Population: Adult male and female subjects with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who are considered sensitive or naïve to proteasome inhibitors, have received 1 to 3 prior lines of therapy for multiple myeloma, and have measurable disease per International Myeloma Working Group (IMWG) criteria.

estimatedDurations.treatmentPeriodDescription: Subjects will receive venetoclax/placebo plus Bd until documented disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, withdrawal of consent, or the subject meets other criteria for discontinuation per study protocol.

provenance.text_snippet:
Screening
Unless otherwise specified, screening procedures must be performed within 21 days prior to 
randomization, including disease assessments per the IMWG criteria.
Approximately 280 subjects at approximately 120 sites will be randomized in a 2:1 ratio to receive an oral daily dose of either venetoclax 800 mg or placebo plus Bd, respectively.

Sponsor: AbbVie*

Methodology: 
This is a Phase 3, multicenter, randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled, parallel group study. This 
study is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of venetoclax plus bortezomib and dexamethasone 
(Bd) in subjects with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who are considered sensitive or naïve to 
proteasome inhibitors and have received 1 to 3 prior lines of therapy for multiple myeloma. The study 
will consist of three phases: Screening, Treatment, and Follow-Up.

studyArms.name: Venetoclax + Bortezomib + Dexamethasone
studyArms.label: Arm 1
studyArms.description: Venetoclax 800 mg orally once daily in combination with Bortezomib 1.3 mg/m² subcutaneously or intravenously and Dexamethasone 20 mg orally on a cyclical schedule.

modificationTriggers.condition: Grade 3/4 neutropenia with infection or fever; or Grade 4 hematologic toxicities (except lymphopenia) - First episode
modificationTriggers.holdCriteria: Until resolved to Grade 1 or baseline level, then resume at same dose.

provenance.text_snippet: First episode: Interrupt venetoclax/placebo and once the toxicity has resolved to Grade 1 or baseline level, venetoclax/placebo may be resumed at the same dose.

modificationTriggers.condition: Grade 3/4 neutropenia with infection or fever; or Grade 4 hematologic toxicities (except lymphopenia) - Subsequent episodes
modificationTriggers.holdCriteria: Until resolution, then resume at reduced dose.

provenance.text_snippet: For subsequent episodes: Interrupt venetoclax/placebo. Consider using G-CSF as clinically indicated. Follow dose reduction guidelines in Table 7 when resuming treatment with venetoclax/placebo after resolution.

modificationTriggers.holdCriteria: Upon resolution, treatment can be resumed at a reduced dose or discontinued.

provenance.text_snippet:
Grade ≥ 3 or Serious Infections
Interrupt venetoclax/placebo and upon resolution, treatment can be resumed at a reduced dose or discontinued, depending on Investigator's clinical judgment.

modificationTriggers.condition: Grade 3 or 4 non-hematologic events - Subsequent episodes
modificationTriggers.holdCriteria: Until resolved to Grade <= 1 or baseline, then resume at reduced dose.

provenance.text_snippet: For subsequent episodes: Interrupt venetoclax/placebo. Follow dose reduction guidelines in Table 7 when resuming treatment with venetoclax/placebo after resolution.

modificationTriggers.condition: Blood chemistry changes suggestive of TLS requiring more than 48 hours to resolve

provenance.text_snippet: For any blood chemistry changes requiring more than 48 hours to resolve, resume at a reduced dose (see Table 7).
If the dose of venetoclax/placebo at dose level –3 is not tolerable, then no further reductions will be allowed and venetoclax/placebo should be discontinued.
AbbVie Investigational Product: Venetoclax (ABT-199)

modificationTriggers.condition: Grade 3 non-hematological or Grade 4 hematological toxicity
modificationTriggers.holdCriteria: Until symptoms resolve, then reinitiate at a 25% reduced dose.

provenance.text_snippet: Withhold bortezomib therapy until the symptoms of the toxicity resolve. When toxicity resolves, bortezomib therapy may be reinitiated at a 25% reduced dose. (1.3 mg/m2 reduces to 1 mg/m2/dose; 1 mg/m2/dose reduces to 0.7 mg/m2/dose).

modificationTriggers.condition: Peripheral Neuropathy Grade 2 with pain or Grade 3
modificationTriggers.holdCriteria: Until toxicity resolves to baseline or <= Grade 1, then reinitiate at 0.7 mg/m² once per week.

provenance.text_snippet:
Grade 2 with pain or Grade 3 (severe symptoms; limiting self care ADLc)
Withhold bortezomib therapy until toxicity resolves to baseline or ≥ Grade 1. When toxicity resolves, reinitiate with a reduced dose of bortezomib at 0.7 mg/m2 once per week.
Table 10. Dose Reductions and Treatment Guidelines for Toxicity Related to Bortezomib
Reference Therapy: Bortezomib powder for solution for injection

Table 11. Dose Reductions for Dexamethasone
Table 12. Treatment Guidelines for Toxicity Related to Dexamethasone
Reference Therapy: Dexamethasone tablet
 Arm 1: Venetoclax plus Bd

modificationTriggers.condition: Grade 3 non-hematological or Grade 4 hematological toxicity
modificationTriggers.holdCriteria: Until symptoms resolve, then reinitiate at a 25% reduced dose.

modificationTriggers.condition: Peripheral Neuropathy Grade 2 with pain or Grade 3
modificationTriggers.holdCriteria: Until toxicity resolves to baseline or <= Grade 1, then reinitiate at 0.7 mg/m² once per week.

studyEpochs.name: Screening
studyEpochs.description: Screening procedures must be performed within 21 days prior to randomization.

provenance.text_snippet:
Screening
Unless otherwise specified, screening procedures must be performed within 21 days prior to randomization, including disease assessments per the IMWG criteria.

studyEpochs.name: Treatment
studyEpochs.description: Cycles 1-8 are 21-day cycles. Cycles 9 and beyond are 35-day cycles. Treatment continues until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or other discontinuation criteria are met.

provenance.text_snippet:
Treatment
During Treatment, all subjects will receive venetoclax/placebo orally (PO) once daily (QD) plus Bd as follows beginning on Cycle 1 Day 1.

studyEpochs.name: Follow-up
studyEpochs.description: Includes a Safety Follow-Up Visit approximately 30 days after the last dose of study treatment, followed by survival follow-up.

provenance.text_snippet:
Follow-Up
All subjects should have one Safety Follow-Up Visit approximately 30 days after the last dose of study treatment.
 Arm 1: Venetoclax plus Bd
 Arm 2: Placebo plus Bd
Interactive Response Technology (IRT) will be utilized to register (screen, re-screen and randomize) subjects on study.

provenance.text_snippet: and the number of prior lines of therapy (1 versus 2 or 3).

_agentDocumentation.purpose:
Extracts the complete treatment design including study arms, epochs, dosing regimens,
    randomization configuration, and drug supply requirements. This is the primary source
    for IRT/IWRS and drug supply management system configuration.
_agentDocumentation.scope:
- Study arms (experimental, comparator, placebo)
    - Treatment epochs (screening, treatment, follow-up)
    - Study cells (arm × epoch matrix)
    - Dosing regimens (dose, frequency, route, cycle length)
    - Dose modification rules and triggers
    - Randomization details (ratio, stratification, block size, algorithm)
    - Drug supply kit configurations

keyInsights.name: Study Arms
keyInsights.description: Complete arm definitions with interventions, types, and allocation ratios

automationRules.description: Generate IRT arm configuration from study arms
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH arm IN studyArms:
                        CREATE irt_arm {
                            arm_code: arm.id,
                            arm_name: arm.name,
                            arm_type: arm.type.decode,
                            allocation: arm.allocationPercentage,
                            interventions: arm.interventions[].name
                        }
automationRules.example: {"arm_code": "A", "arm_name": "Drug + Chemo", "allocation": 66.7}

automationRules.description: Generate treatment assignment dropdown options
automationRules.ruleLogic: CREATE codelist 'TREATMENT_ARM' WITH values FROM studyArms[].name

keyInsights.name: Dosing Regimens
keyInsights.description: Dose, unit, frequency, route, cycle length, dose calculation basis

automationRules.description: Configure IRT dispensing rules from dosing regimen
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH regimen:
                        SET dispense_quantity = regimen.dose * regimen.frequency * cycle_length
                        SET kit_type = DERIVE_KIT(regimen.route, regimen.formulation)
                        SET dispense_visits = MATCH(soa_schedule.visits, regimen.schedule)
automationRules.example: 400mg BID x 28 days = 56 tablets per cycle, dispense at Day 1 of each cycle

automationRules.description: Validate dispensed dose against protocol regimen
automationRules.ruleLogic: IF dispensed_dose != protocol_dose AND NOT dose_modification THEN RAISE query

keyInsights.name: Stratification Factors
keyInsights.description: Randomization stratification with levels and definitions

automationRules.description: Configure IRT stratification from protocol factors
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH factor:
                        CREATE strat_factor {
                            name: factor.name,
                            levels: factor.levels[],
                            edc_field: DERIVE_FIELD(factor.name)
                        }
                    GENERATE strat_combinations = CARTESIAN_PRODUCT(all_factors.levels)
automationRules.example: ECOG (0-1, 2) × Prior Therapy (Yes, No) = 4 strata

automationRules.description: Generate stratification CRF fields
automationRules.ruleLogic: FOR EACH factor: CREATE dropdown_field WITH options = factor.levels

keyInsights.name: Dose Modification Rules
keyInsights.description: Reduction levels, triggers, hold/resume criteria

automationRules.description: Validate dose modification follows protocol levels
automationRules.ruleLogic:
IF new_dose NOT IN allowed_dose_levels THEN RAISE 'Invalid dose level'
                    IF dose_reduction_reason IS NULL THEN RAISE 'Reason required for dose modification'

keyInsights.name: Drug Supply Configuration
keyInsights.description: Kit types, dispensing schedule, supply model

automationRules.description: Generate kit configuration and depot requirements
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH kit_type:
                        SET initial_depot_stock = enrollment_target * cycles * safety_stock_factor
                        SET reorder_point = site_average_enrollment * lead_time_days

objectives.name: Primary Objective
objectives.text: To compare the progression-free survival (PFS) between treatment arms in subjects with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who are considered sensitive or naïve to proteasome inhibitors and received 1 to 3 prior lines of therapy for multiple myeloma.

provenance.text_snippet: The primary objective of the study is to compare the progression-free survival (PFS) between treatment arms in subjects with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who are considered sensitive or naïve to proteasome inhibitors and received 1 to 3 prior lines of therapy for multiple myeloma.

objectives.name: Secondary Efficacy Objectives
objectives.text: To compare, between treatment arms, the following: Very Good Partial Response (VGPR) or better response rate; PFS in subjects with high BCL-2 expression; duration of response (DOR); Patient Reported Outcomes (PRO); overall survival (OS); time to disease progression (TTP); objective response rate (ORR); and minimal residual disease (MRD) negativity rate.

provenance.text_snippet: The secondary objectives are to compare, between treatment arms, the following: Very Good Partial Response (VGPR) or better response rate; PFS in subjects with high BCL-2 expression; duration of response (DOR); Patient Reported Outcomes (PRO) including Worst Pain (Brief Pain Inventory – Short Form [BPI-SF]), Physical Functioning and Global Health Status/Quality of Life (GHS/QoL) (European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire Core [EORTC QLQ-C30]), and

objectives.name: Secondary Safety Objective
objectives.text: To compare safety between treatment arms.

provenance.text_snippet: The secondary objectives are to compare, between treatment arms, the following: ... and safety.

objectives.name: Exploratory Objectives
objectives.text: To assess clinical benefit rate (CBR), disease control rate (DCR), time to response (TTR), time to next treatment (TNT), other PRO endpoints, and a preliminary assessment of potential biomarkers for association with PK, safety and efficacy.

provenance.text_snippet: The tertiary objectives of the study are to assess clinical benefit rate (CBR), disease control rate (DCR), time to response (TTR), time to next treatment (TNT), other PRO endpoints (remaining subscales/items from BPI-SF, EORTC QLQ-C30, European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire Multiple Myeloma Module [EORTC QLQ-MY20], and Euroqol EQ-5D-5L), and a preliminary assessment of potential biomarkers for association with PK, safety and efficacy.

endpoints.name: Progression-Free Survival (PFS)
endpoints.label: Primary Efficacy Endpoint
endpoints.text: Time from randomization to the first documented disease progression (PD) per IMWG criteria or death due to any cause, whichever occurs first.
endpoints.purpose: To assess the effect of treatment on disease progression or death.

provenance.text_snippet:
Primary Efficacy Endpoint:
The primary efficacy endpoint is PFS. PFS is defined as the time from randomization to the first documented PD or death due to any cause, whichever occurs first. The primary analysis of PFS will be based on data from the IRC's assessment of disease progression.

endpoints.name: Very Good Partial Response (VGPR) or Better Response Rate
endpoints.label: Secondary Efficacy Endpoint
endpoints.text: Proportion of subjects with documented Complete Response (CR), stringent Complete Response (sCR), or VGPR.
endpoints.purpose: To assess deep tumor response to treatment.

provenance.text_snippet: VGPR or better response rate is defined as the proportion of subjects with documented Complete Response (CR), stringent Complete Response (sCR), or VGPR.

endpoints.name: Overall Survival (OS)
endpoints.label: Secondary Efficacy Endpoint
endpoints.text: Time from randomization to death due to any cause.
endpoints.purpose: To assess the effect of treatment on survival.

provenance.text_snippet: OS is defined as time from randomization to death due to any cause.

endpoints.name: PFS in Subjects with High BCL-2 Expression
endpoints.label: Secondary Efficacy Endpoint
endpoints.text: Time from randomization to PD or death in the subgroup of subjects with high BCL-2 expression.
endpoints.purpose: To assess treatment effect in a biomarker-defined subgroup.

provenance.text_snippet: Secondary efficacy endpoints are as follows: ... PFS in subjects with high BCL-2 expression

endpoints.name: Duration of Response (DOR)
endpoints.label: Secondary Efficacy Endpoint
endpoints.text: Time from first documented response (PR or better) to the date of first documented PD or death due to multiple myeloma, whichever occurs first.
endpoints.purpose: To assess the durability of response.

provenance.text_snippet: DOR is defined as the time from first documented response (PR or better) to the date of first documented PD or death due to multiple myeloma, whichever occurs first.

endpoints.name: Time to Progression (TTP)
endpoints.label: Secondary Efficacy Endpoint
endpoints.text: Time from randomization to the date of first documented PD or death due to multiple myeloma, whichever occurs first.
endpoints.purpose: To assess time to disease progression.

provenance.text_snippet: TTP is defined as the time from randomization to the date of first documented PD or death due to multiple myeloma, whichever occurs first.

endpoints.name: Objective Response Rate (ORR)
endpoints.label: Secondary Efficacy Endpoint
endpoints.text: Proportion of subjects with documented PR or better.

provenance.text_snippet: ORR is defined as the proportion of subjects with documented PR or better.

endpoints.name: Minimal Residual Disease (MRD) Negativity Rate
endpoints.label: Secondary Efficacy Endpoint
endpoints.text: Proportion of subjects with MRD negativity, defined at 10^-5 threshold as assessed by NGS.
endpoints.purpose: To assess very deep levels of response.

provenance.text_snippet: MRD negativity will be defined at 10–5 threshold as described in Section 5.3.6.

endpoints.name: Patient Reported Outcomes (PROs)
endpoints.label: Secondary Efficacy Endpoint
endpoints.text: Change from baseline in Worst Pain (BPI-SF), Physical Functioning (EORTC QLQ-C30), Global Health Status/Quality of Life (EORTC QLQ-C30), and Fatigue (PROMIS Cancer Fatigue SF).
endpoints.purpose: To assess the impact of treatment on patient-reported symptoms and quality of life.

provenance.text_snippet: Secondary efficacy endpoints are as follows: ... PROs: Worst Pain (BPI-SF), Physical Functioning (EORTC QLQ-C30); ... PROs GHS/QoL (EORTC QLQ-C30), and Fatigue (PROMIS Cancer Fatigue SF).

endpoints.name: Clinical Benefit Rate (CBR)
endpoints.label: Exploratory Endpoint
endpoints.text: Proportion of subjects with documented Minimal Response (MR) or better.
endpoints.purpose: To assess the proportion of subjects deriving clinical benefit.

provenance.text_snippet: CBR is defined as the proportion of subjects with documented MR or better.

endpoints.name: Disease Control Rate (DCR)
endpoints.label: Exploratory Endpoint
endpoints.text: Proportion of subjects with documented MR or better or Stable Disease (SD) lasting at least 8 weeks.
endpoints.purpose: To assess the proportion of subjects with controlled disease.

provenance.text_snippet: DCR is defined as the proportion of subjects with documented MR or better or SD lasting at least 8 weeks.

endpoints.name: Time to Response (TTR)
endpoints.label: Exploratory Endpoint
endpoints.text: Time from randomization to the date of first documented response (PR or better).
endpoints.purpose: To assess the speed of response.

provenance.text_snippet: For a given subject, TTR is defined as the number of days from the date the subject was randomized to the date of first documented response (PR or better).

endpoints.name: Safety and Tolerability
endpoints.label: Safety Endpoint
endpoints.text: Incidence, severity, and causality of adverse events (AEs), serious adverse events (SAEs), and changes in laboratory values, vital signs, and ECGs.
endpoints.purpose: To evaluate the safety profile of the treatment.

provenance.text_snippet:
Safety:
AbbVie will assess adverse events, laboratory data, electrocardiograms (ECG) and vital signs throughout the study. Adverse events intensity and laboratory evaluation changes will be assessed by utilizing National Cancer Institute (NCI) Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) Version 4.03.

estimands.name: Primary Estimand for PFS
estimands.text: Treatment effect on Progression-Free Survival comparing Venetoclax plus Bortezomib and Dexamethasone vs Placebo plus Bortezomib and Dexamethasone in the ITT population.

provenance.text_snippet:
Once screening procedures are complete and eligibility is confirmed, subjects will be randomized 2:1 to one of the following two arms:
Arm 1: Venetoclax plus Bd
Arm 2: Placebo plus Bd

population.description: Intent-to-Treat population, including all randomized subjects.

provenance.text_snippet: Intent-To-Treat (ITT) analysis set consists of all randomized subjects. The data from the ITT population will be analyzed by the treatment group assignment given at the time of randomization, even if the subject does not receive the correct treatment or is not compliant to the protocol procedures.

variable.description: Progression-Free Survival (PFS) per IRC assessment, defined as time from randomization to disease progression or death from any cause.

provenance.text_snippet:
The primary endpoint is PFS based on IMWG criteria for multiple myeloma (Appendix J)13,14 per IRC assessment.

For a given subject, PFS is defined as the number of days from the date the subject was randomized to the date of the first documented PD or death due to any cause, whichever occurs first.

intercurrent_events.name: Discontinuation of study treatment
intercurrent_events.description: Subject discontinues study treatment for reasons other than disease progression (e.g., toxicity, withdrawal of consent).
intercurrent_events.strategy_rationale: All events of PD or death are included, regardless of whether the subject was still taking study drug or had previously discontinued.

provenance.text_snippet: All events of PD will be included, regardless of whether the event occurred while the subject was still taking study drug or had previously discontinued study drug.

intercurrent_events.name: Initiation of new anti-cancer therapy
intercurrent_events.description: Subject starts a new anti-cancer therapy prior to documented disease progression.
intercurrent_events.strategy_rationale: Subjects are censored at the date of the last adequate assessment prior to the start of new anti-cancer therapy.

provenance.text_snippet: Start of new anti-cancer therapy prior to PD/death | If no adequate assessment is available prior to start of new anti-cancer therapy then date of randomization. Otherwise, date of the last adequate assessment prior to start of new anti-cancer therapy | Censor

intercurrent_events.name: Death
intercurrent_events.description: Death without prior documented disease progression.
intercurrent_events.strategy_rationale: Death is a component of the composite endpoint of Progression-Free Survival.

provenance.text_snippet: For a given subject, PFS is defined as the number of days from the date the subject was randomized to the date of the first documented PD or death due to any cause, whichever occurs first.

The study is designed to test the following primary statistical hypothesis:
H0: S(t)Venetoclax + Bd = S(t)Placebo + Bd vs. H1: S(t)Venetoclax +Bd ≠ S(t)Placebo + Bd ,
where S(t) is the survivorship function of PFS at time t.

estimands.name: Estimand for VGPR or better rate
estimands.text: Treatment effect on VGPR or better rate comparing Venetoclax+Bd vs Placebo+Bd in the ITT population.

provenance.text_snippet:
Once screening procedures are complete and eligibility is confirmed, subjects will be randomized 2:1 to one of the following two arms:
Arm 1: Venetoclax plus Bd
Arm 2: Placebo plus Bd

population.description: Intent-to-Treat population, including all randomized subjects.

provenance.text_snippet: Intent-To-Treat (ITT) analysis set consists of all randomized subjects.

variable.description: VGPR or better response rate (CR, sCR, or VGPR).

provenance.text_snippet: VGPR or better response rate is defined as the proportion of subjects with documented CR, sCR, or VGPR.

intercurrent_events.name: Discontinuation of study treatment or death
intercurrent_events.description: Subject discontinues treatment or dies before a response can be assessed or confirmed.
intercurrent_events.strategy_rationale: Subjects who discontinue or die before achieving a response are considered non-responders.

provenance.text_snippet: VGPR or better response rate and ORR will be analyzed by using Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test. Estimated rates along with corresponding 95% confidence intervals will be presented.
VGPR or better response rate and ORR will be analyzed by using Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test.

estimands.name: Estimand for Overall Survival
estimands.text: Treatment effect on Overall Survival comparing Venetoclax+Bd vs Placebo+Bd in the ITT population.

provenance.text_snippet:
Once screening procedures are complete and eligibility is confirmed, subjects will be randomized 2:1 to one of the following two arms:
Arm 1: Venetoclax plus Bd
Arm 2: Placebo plus Bd

population.description: Intent-to-Treat population, including all randomized subjects.

provenance.text_snippet: Intent-To-Treat (ITT) analysis set consists of all randomized subjects.

variable.description: Overall Survival, defined as time from randomization to death from any cause.

provenance.text_snippet: For a given subject, time to death (OS) is defined as the number of days from the date the subject was randomized to the date of the subject's death due to any cause.

intercurrent_events.name: Discontinuation of study treatment or initiation of new anti-cancer therapy
intercurrent_events.description: Subject discontinues assigned treatment and/or initiates subsequent anti-cancer therapy.
intercurrent_events.strategy_rationale: All deaths are included regardless of whether the subject discontinued study drug or received other therapies.

provenance.text_snippet: All events of death will be included, regardless of whether the event occurred while the subject was still taking study drug or after the subject discontinued study drug.
The OS will be analyzed by using a stratified two-sided 3-look group sequential log-rank test with a cumulative two-sided type-I error rate of α = 0.05 (one-sided type I error rate of α = 0.025).

analysis_populations.name: Intent-to-Treat Population
analysis_populations.label: ITT
analysis_populations.text: All randomized subjects. The data from the ITT population will be analyzed by the treatment group assignment given at the time of randomization.

provenance.text_snippet: Intent-To-Treat (ITT) analysis set consists of all randomized subjects. The data from the ITT population will be analyzed by the treatment group assignment given at the time of randomization, even if the subject does not receive the correct treatment or is not compliant to the protocol procedures.

analysis_populations.name: Safety Population
analysis_populations.label: Safety
analysis_populations.text: All randomized subjects who take at least one dose of study drug.
inclusion_criteria: All randomized subjects who received at least one dose of study drug

provenance.text_snippet: Safety analysis set consists of all randomized subjects who take at least one dose of study drug.
4.0 Study Objectives

sensitivity_analyses.name: PFS by Investigator Assessment
sensitivity_analyses.description: The primary PFS analysis will be repeated based on the Investigator's assessment of disease progression.
sensitivity_analyses.purpose: To assess the robustness of the primary PFS result to the choice of assessor (IRC vs Investigator).
sensitivity_analyses.missing_data_handling: Censoring rules as per primary analysis.
sensitivity_analyses.statistical_model: Stratified log-rank test and Cox proportional hazards model.

provenance.text_snippet: 1. PFS based on assessment by Investigator.

sensitivity_analyses.name: PFS using actual event date
sensitivity_analyses.description: The primary PFS analysis will be repeated using the actual event date of PD or death as the event date, regardless of the number of preceding missing assessments.
sensitivity_analyses.purpose: To assess the impact of censoring rules related to missing assessments on the primary PFS result.
sensitivity_analyses.missing_data_handling: No censoring for missing assessments prior to an event.
sensitivity_analyses.statistical_model: Stratified log-rank test and Cox proportional hazards model.

provenance.text_snippet: 2. Using the actual event date of PD or death as event date, regardless of the number of preceding missing assessments.

sensitivity_analyses.name: PFS without censoring for new therapy
sensitivity_analyses.description: The primary PFS analysis will be repeated without considering the start of new anticancer therapy as a reason for censoring.
sensitivity_analyses.purpose: To evaluate a treatment policy strategy for the intercurrent event of starting new anti-cancer therapy.
sensitivity_analyses.missing_data_handling: Subjects are not censored at the start of new anti-cancer therapy.
sensitivity_analyses.statistical_model: Stratified log-rank test and Cox proportional hazards model.

provenance.text_snippet: 3. Not considering taking new anticancer therapy as a reason for censoring.

sensitivity_analyses.name: PFS Robustness Analysis with Covariates
sensitivity_analyses.description: A robustness analysis for PFS will be performed using a stratified, adjusted Cox model.
sensitivity_analyses.purpose: To assess the robustness of the treatment effect after adjusting for important baseline prognostic factors.
sensitivity_analyses.missing_data_handling: Handled by the Cox model for subjects censored for other reasons.

provenance.text_snippet: 4. A robustness analysis will be performed using a stratified, adjusted Cox model, i.e., the MODEL statement will include the treatment group variable; and, e.g., age group (< 65 years/≥ 65 years), renal function, cytogenetic (high risk/standard risk), prior stem cell transplant (yes/no), BCL-2 expression (high/low) and MM stage as covariates.

statistical_methods.name: Primary Analysis of PFS
statistical_methods.description: A stratified two-sided log-rank test will be used to test PFS. The hazards ratio (HR) for treatment effect will be estimated from a Cox's proportional hazards model with treatment and stratification factors included. Survivorship functions will be estimated using the Kaplan-Meier method.
stratification_factors: prior exposure to bortezomib or other proteasome inhibitors (proteasome inhibitor-naïve versus proteasome inhibitor-sensitive)
number of prior lines of therapy (1 versus 2 or 3)

provenance.text_snippet: For PFS, a stratified two-sided log-rank test with two-sided type-I error rate of α = 0.05 (one-sided type I error rate of α = 0.025) will be used to test the primary null hypothesis. The hazards ratio (HR) for treatment effect will be estimated and its two-sided 95% confidence interval will be provided. The estimation will be based on a Cox's proportional hazards model with treatment and stratification factors included.

statistical_methods.name: Analysis of Binary Endpoints
statistical_methods.description: VGPR or better response rate, ORR, MRD negativity rate, CBR, and DCR will be analyzed by using Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test. Estimated rates along with corresponding 95% confidence intervals will be presented.

provenance.text_snippet: VGPR or better response rate and ORR will be analyzed by using Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test. Estimated rates along with corresponding 95% confidence intervals will be presented.

statistical_methods.name: Analysis of Overall Survival
statistical_methods.description: OS will be analyzed by using a stratified two-sided 3-look group sequential log-rank test with a cumulative two-sided type-I error rate of α = 0.05. The HR will be estimated from a Cox's proportional hazards model.
stratification_factors: prior exposure to bortezomib or other proteasome inhibitors (proteasome inhibitor-naïve versus proteasome inhibitor-sensitive)
number of prior lines of therapy (1 versus 2 or 3)

provenance.text_snippet: The OS will be analyzed by using a stratified two-sided 3-look group sequential log-rank test with a cumulative two-sided type-I error rate of α = 0.05 (one-sided type I error rate of α = 0.025). The hazards ratio for treatment effect will be estimated and its two-sided 95% confidence interval will be provided. The estimation will be based on a Cox's proportional hazards model with treatment and stratification factors in it.

statistical_methods.name: Analysis of Other Time-to-Event Endpoints
statistical_methods.description: PFS in subjects with high BCL-2 expression, DOR, TTP, TTR, and TNT will be analyzed by using stratified log-rank test. The HRs will be estimated from a Cox's proportional hazards model.
stratification_factors: prior exposure to bortezomib or other proteasome inhibitors (proteasome inhibitor-naïve versus proteasome inhibitor-sensitive)
number of prior lines of therapy (1 versus 2 or 3)

provenance.text_snippet:
DOR and TTP will be analyzed by using stratified log-rank test.

The hazards ratios for treatment effect will be estimated and two-sided 95% confidence intervals will be provided. The estimation will be based on a Cox's proportional hazards model with treatment and stratification factors in it.

statistical_methods.name: Analysis of Patient-Reported Outcomes
statistical_methods.description: For PROs, change in score from baseline will be compared between treatment arms. Descriptive statistics will be used to summarize outcomes.

provenance.text_snippet: For PROs, change in score from baseline will be compared between treatment arms for the following domains: Worst Pain (BPI-SF), Physical Functioning (EORTC QLQ-C30), Fatigue (PROMIS-Fatigue), and Global Health Status/QoL (EORTC QLQ-C30).

subgroup_analyses.description: A subgroup analysis will be performed for the primary endpoint PFS by BCL-2 expression levels (high/low).

multiplicity_adjustment.description: Statistical testing of the secondary endpoints will be performed only if the primary efficacy analysis of PFS is significant. The testing order and details of testing procedures will be provided in the SAP.
multiplicity_adjustment.alpha_allocation: Overall family-wise two-sided type I error rate of 0.05.
multiplicity_adjustment.gatekeeping_strategy: The primary endpoint of PFS serves as the gatekeeper for testing secondary endpoints.

provenance.text_snippet: Statistical tests for the secondary endpoints will be implemented in the testing strategy to maintain family-wise two-sided type I error rate at 0.05. Each of these tests will be performed at an overall two-sided significance level of 0.05. Statistical testing of the secondary endpoints will be performed only if the primary efficacy analysis of PFS is significant.

missing_data_handling.method_description: For time-to-event endpoints (PFS, OS, DOR, TTP), data for subjects who do not experience the event of interest by the end of the study or are lost to follow-up will be censored at the last date they were known to be event-free. Specific censoring rules are defined for different scenarios, such as missing assessments or starting new anti-cancer therapy.

_agentDocumentation.purpose:
Extracts study objectives, endpoints, estimands (per ICH E9 R1), analysis populations,
    and statistical analysis specifications. This is the definitive source for programming
    analysis datasets and statistical outputs.
_agentDocumentation.scope:
- Primary, secondary, and exploratory objectives
    - Endpoint definitions with outcome types and assessment methods
    - ICH E9(R1) compliant estimands with intercurrent event strategies
    - Analysis populations (ITT, mITT, PP, Safety)
    - Sensitivity and subgroup analyses
    - Multiplicity adjustment strategy
    - Missing data handling

keyInsights.name: Primary Endpoints
keyInsights.description: Primary efficacy endpoints with outcome type, timepoints, and assessment method

automationRules.description: Generate ADaM ADEFF specification from primary endpoint
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH primary_endpoint:
                        CREATE adam_spec {
                            dataset: 'ADEFF' or 'ADTTE',
                            paramcd: DERIVE_PARAMCD(endpoint.name),
                            param: endpoint.text,
                            dtype: endpoint.outcome_type.decode,
                            avisit: endpoint.primary_timepoint_text
                        }

keyInsights.name: Estimands
keyInsights.description: ICH E9(R1) estimands with treatment comparison, population, variable, ICE strategies

automationRules.description: Generate SAP estimand section from extracted estimands
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH estimand:
                        GENERATE estimand_table {
                            population: estimand.population.description,
                            treatment: estimand.treatment,
                            variable: estimand.variable.description,
                            intercurrent_events: estimand.intercurrent_events[],
                            summary_measure: estimand.summary_measure.decode
                        }

                            flag_name: population.label + 'FL',

                            inclusion_criteria: population.inclusion_criteria,

ae_definitions.ae_definition: Any untoward medical occurrence in a patient or clinical investigation subject administered a pharmaceutical product and which does not necessarily have a causal relationship with this treatment. An adverse event can therefore be any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a medicinal (investigational) product, whether or not the event is considered causally related to the use of the product.
ae_definitions.teae_definition: Any adverse event with onset or worsening reported by a subject from the time that the first dose of venetoclax/placebo, bortezomib, or dexamethasone is administered until 30 days have elapsed following discontinuation of venetoclax/placebo, bortezomib, and dexamethasone administration.
ae_definitions.collection_start: signing of the study specific informed consent
ae_definitions.collection_end: 30 days following discontinuation of study treatment administration
ae_definitions.pre_existing_condition_handling: Any worsening of a pre-existing condition or illness is considered an adverse event.

provenance.text_snippet: An adverse event is defined as any untoward medical occurrence in a patient or clinical investigation subject administered a pharmaceutical product and which does not necessarily have a causal relationship with this treatment... Any worsening of a pre-existing condition or illness is considered an adverse event.

sae_criteria.sae_definition: An adverse event that meets any of the following criteria: Death of Subject, Life-Threatening, Hospitalization or Prolongation of Hospitalization, Congenital Anomaly, Persistent or Significant Disability/Incapacity, Important Medical Event.

criteria.definition: An event that results in the death of a subject.

provenance.text_snippet: Death of Subject An event that results in the death of a subject.

criteria.definition: An event that, in the opinion of the Investigator, would have resulted in immediate fatality if medical intervention had not been taken. This does not include an event that would have been fatal if it had occurred in a more severe form.

provenance.text_snippet: Life-Threatening An event that, in the opinion of the Investigator, would have resulted in immediate fatality if medical intervention had not been taken. This does not include an event that would have been fatal if it had occurred in a more severe form.

criteria.definition: An event that results in an admission to the hospital for any length of time.
exclusions: Emergency room visit or admission to an outpatient facility.

provenance.text_snippet: Hospitalization or Prolongation of Hospitalization: An event that results in an admission to the hospital for any length of time or prolongs the subject's hospital stay. This does not include an emergency room visit or admission to an outpatient facility.

criteria.definition: An event that prolongs the subject's hospital stay.

provenance.text_snippet: Hospitalization or Prolongation of Hospitalization: An event that results in an admission to the hospital for any length of time or prolongs the subject's hospital stay.

criteria.definition: An event that results in a condition that substantially interferes with the activities of daily living of a study subject.
exclusions: Experiences of relatively minor medical significance such as headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, influenza, and accidental trauma (e.g., sprained ankle).

provenance.text_snippet: Persistent or Significant Disability/Incapacity: An event that results in a condition that substantially interferes with the activities of daily living of a study subject. Disability is not intended to include experiences of relatively minor medical significance such as headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, influenza, and accidental trauma (e.g., sprained ankle).

criteria.definition: An anomaly detected at or after birth, or any anomaly that results in fetal loss.

provenance.text_snippet: Congenital Anomaly: An anomaly detected at or after birth, or any anomaly that results in fetal loss.

criteria.definition: An important medical event that may not be immediately life-threatening or result in death or hospitalization, but based on medical judgment may jeopardize the subject and may require medical or surgical intervention to prevent any of the outcomes listed above (i.e., death of subject, life-threatening, hospitalization, prolongation of hospitalization, congenital anomaly, or persistent or significant disability/incapacity). Additionally, any elective or spontaneous abortion or stillbirth is considered an important medical event. Examples of such events include allergic bronchospasm requiring intensive treatment in an emergency room or at home, blood dyscrasias or convulsions that do not result in inpatient hospitalization, or the development of drug dependency or drug abuse.

provenance.text_snippet: Important Medical Event Requiring Medical or Surgical Intervention to Prevent Serious Outcome: An important medical event that may not be immediately life-threatening or result in death or hospitalization, but based on medical judgment may jeopardize the subject and may require medical or surgical intervention to prevent any of the outcomes listed above...
If an adverse event meets any of the following criteria, it is to be reported to AbbVie as a serious adverse event (SAE) within 24 hours of the site being made aware of the serious adverse event:

grade_definitions.label: Mild
grade_definitions.definition: The adverse event is transient and easily tolerated by the subject (mild).

grade_definitions.label: Moderate
grade_definitions.definition: The adverse event causes the subject discomfort and interrupts the subject's usual activities (moderate).

grade_definitions.label: Severe
grade_definitions.definition: The adverse event causes considerable interference with the subject's usual activities and may be incapacitating (moderate to severe).

grade_definitions.label: Life-threatening
grade_definitions.definition: The adverse event is life threatening requiring urgent intervention (severe).

grade_definitions.label: Death
grade_definitions.definition: The adverse event resulted in death of the subject (severe).

provenance.text_snippet: The Investigator will rate the severity of each adverse event according to the National Cancer Institute Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (NCI CTCAE Version 4.03). For adverse events not captured by the Common Terminology Criteria, the following should be used: Grade 1 The adverse event is transient and easily tolerated by the subject (mild). Grade 2 The adverse event causes the subject discomfort and interrupts the subject's usual activities (moderate).

causality_assessment.method_description: The Investigator will assess the relationship of each adverse event to venetoclax, to bortezomib, and to dexamethasone.

categories.definition: An adverse event where there is evidence to suggest a causal relationship between the study treatment and the adverse event.
An adverse event where there is no evidence to suggest a causal relationship between the study treatment and the adverse event.

provenance.text_snippet:
The Investigator will use the following definitions to assess the relationship of the adverse event to the use of the study treatment:
Reasonable Possibility: An adverse event where there is evidence to suggest a causal relationship between the study treatment and the adverse event.
No Reasonable Possibility: An adverse event where there is no evidence to suggest a causal relationship between the study treatment and the adverse event.

Treatment-emergent adverse events will be coded and summarized by system organ class and preferred term according to the Medical Dictionary for Regulatory Activities (MedDRA) adverse event coding dictionary.

sae_reporting.method: SAE data entry into EDC RAVE® system. If RAVE is not operable, documented on the SAE Non-CRF forms and emailed or faxed to Clinical Pharmacovigilance.

provenance.text_snippet: In the event of a serious adverse event, whether associated with the study treatment or not, the Investigator will notify Clinical Pharmacovigilance within 24 hours of the site being made aware of the serious adverse event by entering the serious adverse event data into EDC RAVE® system. Serious adverse events that occur prior to the site having access to the RAVE® system, or if RAVE® is not operable, should be documented on the SAE Non-CRF forms and emailed (preferred route) or faxed to

Pregnancy in a study subject must be reported to an AbbVie representative (Section 6.1.5) within 1 working day of the site becoming aware of the pregnancy... In the event of a pregnancy occurring in the partner of an enrolled subject, written informed consent for release of medical information from the partner must be obtained prior to the collection of any pregnancy-specific information, and the pregnancy will be followed to outcome.

reporting_procedures.unblinding_procedures: The IRT system can provide access to blinded subject treatment information during the study if identification of the study drug is required for medical emergency, i.e., situation in which the knowledge of the specific blinded treatment will affect the immediate management of the subject/subject's conditions (e.g., antidote is available). AbbVie must then be notified within 24 hours of the blind being broken.

provenance.text_snippet: The IRT system can provide access to blinded subject treatment information during the study if identification of the study drug is required for medical emergency, i.e., situation in which the knowledge of the specific blinded treatment will affect the immediate management of the subject/subject's conditions (e.g., antidote is available). AbbVie must then be notified within 24 hours of the blind being broken.

safety_committees.charter_availability: Details of the IDMC review will be outlined in the IDMC Charter.
safety_committees.responsibilities: Periodically review the safety and efficacy data for this study in an un-blinded fashion. Aggregate blinded clinical safety and efficacy data will be reviewed on a real-time basis throughout the course of the study. Once the final Overall Survival (OS) analysis is complete, a final review of safety and efficacy data will be conducted by the IDMC.

provenance.text_snippet: An IDMC will periodically review the safety and efficacy data for this study in an un-blinded fashion. Aggregate blinded clinical safety and efficacy data will be reviewed on a real-time basis throughout the course of the study. Once the final Overall Survival (OS) analysis is complete (refer to Section 8.1.5.5.2), a final review of safety and efficacy data will be conducted by the IDMC. AbbVie will continue to monitor subjects' safety data after the final IDMC meeting.

6.1 Medical Complaints
The Investigator will monitor each subject for clinical and laboratory evidence of adverse events on a routine basis throughout the study.

Extracts comprehensive adverse event management specifications including AE/SAE definitions,
    grading systems, causality assessment, reporting timelines, and AESI lists. Critical for
    safety database configuration and pharmacovigilance workflows.

- AE and TEAE definitions
    - SAE criteria per ICH E2A
    - CTCAE grading system version and definitions
    - Causality assessment methodology
    - MedDRA coding specifications
    - Reporting timelines (routine AE, SAE, SUSAR, pregnancy)
    - AESI list with special monitoring requirements
    - DLT criteria (oncology protocols)
    - Safety committees (DSMB, SMC)

automationRules.description: Validate AE dates within collection period
automationRules.ruleLogic:
IF ae.start_date < first_dose_date THEN SET ae.treatment_emergent = 'N'
                    IF ae.start_date > last_dose_date + followup_days THEN RAISE 'AE outside collection window'
automationRules.example: AE start date must be >= first dose date for TEAE flag

keyInsights.name: SAE Criteria
keyInsights.description: ICH E2A serious criteria with protocol-specific exceptions

automationRules.description: Configure SAE detection and expedited reporting workflow
automationRules.ruleLogic:
IF any(sae_criteria) THEN:
                        SET serious_flag = 'Y'
                        SET report_due_hours = sae_criteria.initial_report_hours
                        TRIGGER expedited_workflow
                        NOTIFY medical_monitor, sponsor_safety
automationRules.example: Death → 24hr initial report, 7-day follow-up

automationRules.description: Enforce SAE documentation requirements
automationRules.ruleLogic:
IF serious = 'Y' THEN REQUIRE (
                        seriousness_criteria IS NOT NULL,
                        onset_date IS NOT NULL,
                        outcome IS NOT NULL,
                        causality IS NOT NULL
                    )

keyInsights.name: Reporting Timelines
keyInsights.description: Hours/days for initial SAE report, follow-up, SUSAR

automationRules.description: Configure safety reporting timeline workflows
automationRules.ruleLogic:
CREATE workflow_rules:
                        - SAE initial: due_hours = reporting_procedures.sae_initial_hours
                        - SAE followup: due_days = reporting_procedures.sae_followup_days
                        - SUSAR: due_days = 15 (unexpected), 7 (fatal/life-threatening)
                    SET escalation_path = [site, medical_monitor, sponsor_safety, regulatory]

keyInsights.name: AESI List

automationRules.description: Prompt for AESI-specific data collection
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH aesi:
                        IF ae.meddra_pt IN aesi.matching_terms THEN:
                            DISPLAY aesi.additional_questions
                            SET aesi_flag = 'Y'
                            IF aesi.immediate_notification THEN NOTIFY medical_monitor
automationRules.example: Hepatotoxicity → Prompt for Hy's Law labs, trigger medical monitor alert

keyInsights.name: DLT Criteria
keyInsights.description: Dose-limiting toxicity definitions, observation period, MTD rules

automationRules.description: Configure DLT-based dose escalation rules
automationRules.ruleLogic:
SET dlt_window_days = dlt_criteria.observation_period_days
                    SET escalation_rules = {
                        '0 DLTs in 3': 'ESCALATE',
                        '1 DLT in 3': 'EXPAND to 6',
                        '1 DLT in 6': 'ESCALATE',
                        '>=2 DLTs in 6': 'MTD exceeded, DE-ESCALATE'
                    }

decision_rules.rule_description: Administer G-CSF for neutropenia if clinically indicated.

conditions.description: Grade 3 or 4 neutropenia with infection or fever.

actions.action_description: G-CSF or growth factors for neutropenia may be administered.

provenance.text_snippet: G-CSF or growth factors for neutropenia may be administered with venetoclax/placebo if clinically indicated.

decision_rules.rule_description: Administer antibiotic prophylaxis for Grade 4 neutropenia without infection.

conditions.description: Grade 4 neutropenia without infection.

actions.action_description: Administer Levofloxacin (500 mg once daily) or equivalent until neutropenia improves to Grade 3 or better (ANC > 500 cells/µL).

provenance.text_snippet: For Grade 4 neutropenia without infection, anti-infective prophylaxis with Levofloxacin (500 mg once daily, adjusted for renal function) or equivalent antibiotic therapy, per institutional guidelines must be administered until the neutropenia improves to Grade 3 or better (ANC > 500 cells/µL) (See Section 6.1.7.1).

decision_rules.rule_description: First episode of Grade 3/4 neutropenia with infection/fever or Grade 4 hematologic toxicity.

conditions.description: First episode of Grade 3 or 4 neutropenia with infection or fever; or Grade 4 hematologic toxicities (except lymphopenia).

actions.action_description: Interrupt venetoclax/placebo.

recovery_criteria.description: Resume at the same dose once the toxicity has resolved to Grade 1 or baseline level.

provenance.text_snippet: First episode: Interrupt venetoclax/placebo and once the toxicity has resolved to Grade 1 or baseline level, venetoclax/placebo may be resumed at the same dose.

decision_rules.rule_description: Subsequent episodes of Grade 3/4 neutropenia with infection/fever or Grade 4 hematologic toxicity.

conditions.description: Subsequent episode of Grade 3 or 4 neutropenia with infection or fever; or Grade 4 hematologic toxicities (except lymphopenia).

actions.action_description: Interrupt venetoclax/placebo.
Resume treatment at a reduced dose level per Table 7 after resolution.

provenance.text_snippet: For subsequent episodes: Interrupt venetoclax/placebo. Consider using G-CSF as clinically indicated. Follow dose reduction guidelines in Table 7 when resuming treatment with venetoclax/placebo after resolution.
Grade 3 or Grade 4 neutropenia with infection or fever; or Grade 4 hematologic toxicities (except for lymphopenia)

actions.action_description: Interrupt venetoclax/placebo.

actions.action_description: Interrupt venetoclax/placebo.

conditions.description: Co-administration with a moderate CYP3A inhibitor.

actions.action_description: Reduce the current venetoclax/placebo dose by 50% (e.g., 800mg to 400mg, 600mg to 300mg, etc.).

recovery_criteria.description: After discontinuation of CYP3A inhibitor, wait for 3 days before venetoclax/placebo dose is increased back to previous dose level.

provenance.text_snippet: If the administration of a moderate or strong CYP3A4 is absolutely necessary based on the investigator's clinical judgment, then the venetoclax/placebo dose should be reduced during the period it is co-administered with a moderate or strong CYP3A4... After discontinuation of CYP3A inhibitor, wait for 3 days before venetoclax/placebo dose is increased back to previous dose level.
With Moderate CYP3A Inhibitor

After discontinuation of CYP3A inhibitor, wait for 3 days before venetoclax/placebo dose is increased back to previous dose level.

decision_rules.rule_description: Dose reduction for Grade 3 non-hematological or Grade 4 hematological toxicity related to Bortezomib.

conditions.description: Grade 3 non-hematological or Grade 4 hematological (other than neuropathy).

actions.action_description: Withhold bortezomib therapy until symptoms resolve.
Reinitiate at a 25% reduced dose (1.3 mg/m2 to 1 mg/m2; 1 mg/m2 to 0.7 mg/m2).

provenance.text_snippet: Withhold bortezomib therapy until the symptoms of the toxicity resolve. When toxicity resolves, bortezomib therapy may be reinitiated at a 25% reduced dose. (1.3 mg/m2 reduces to 1 mg/m2/dose; 1 mg/m2/dose reduces to 0.7 mg/m2/dose).
Grade 3 non-hematological or Grade 4 hematological (other than neuropathy)

decision_rules.rule_description: Dose modification for Grade 1 with pain or Grade 2 peripheral neuropathy.

conditions.description: Grade 1 with pain or Grade 2 (moderate symptoms; limiting instrumental ADL).

actions.action_description: For subjects on twice-weekly bortezomib, change schedule to 1.3 mg/m2 once per week.
Alternatively, reduce bortezomib current dose by one level.

provenance.text_snippet: For subjects receiving twice-weekly bortezomib, only, change treatment schedule to 1.3 mg/m2 once per week (Day 1, 8 and 15 in a 21-day cycle) OR Reduce bortezomib current dose by one level (1.3 mg/m2 to 1 mg/m2 to 0.7 mg/m2)

decision_rules.rule_description: Dose modification for Grade 2 with pain or Grade 3 peripheral neuropathy.

conditions.description: Grade 2 with pain or Grade 3 (severe symptoms; limiting self care ADL).

actions.action_description: Withhold bortezomib therapy.
When toxicity resolves, reinitiate with a reduced dose of bortezomib at 0.7 mg/m2 once per week.

recovery_criteria.description: Toxicity resolves to baseline or ≤ Grade 1.

provenance.text_snippet: Withhold bortezomib therapy until toxicity resolves to baseline or ≥ Grade 1. When toxicity resolves, reinitiate with a reduced dose of bortezomib at 0.7 mg/m2 once per week.
Peripheral Neuropathy:a

decision_rules.rule_description: Dose reduction for persistent Grade 1-2 GI toxicity.

conditions.description: Dyspepsia, gastric or duodenal ulcer, gastritis Grades 1–2 that persists despite supportive measures.

actions.action_description: Treat with H2 blockers, sucralfate, or proton pump inhibitor.
If symptoms persist, decrease dexamethasone dose by 1 dose level.

provenance.text_snippet: Treat with H2 blockers, sucralfate, or proton pump inhibitor. If symptoms persist despite above measures, decrease dexamethasone dose by 1 dose level.

decision_rules.rule_description: Dose modification for Grade 3 or higher GI toxicity.

conditions.description: Grade 3 or higher GI toxicity requiring hospitalization or surgery.

actions.action_description: Hold dexamethasone until symptoms adequately controlled.
Restart at 1 dose decrement. If symptoms persist, reduce to dose level –3 or discontinue permanently.

provenance.text_snippet: Hold dexamethasone until symptoms adequately controlled. Restart at 1 dose decrement along with concurrent therapy with H2 blockers, sucralfate, or proton pump inhibitor. If symptoms persist despite above measures, reduce to dose level –3 or discontinue dexamethasone permanently.
Gastrointestinal

decision_rules.rule_description: Dose modification for Grade 3 or higher edema.

conditions.description: Edema ≥ Grade 3 (limiting function and unresponsive to therapy or anasarca).

actions.action_description: Diuretics as needed.
Restart dexamethasone at 1 dose decrement. If edema persists, decrease dose by another level. If it persists again, discontinue permanently.

provenance.text_snippet: Diuretics as needed, and restart dexamethasone at 1 dose decrement; if edema persists despite above measures, decrease dose by another level. Discontinue dexamethasone permanently if symptoms persist despite second reduction.
Cardiovascular Edema ≥ Grade 3 (limiting function and unresponsive to therapy or anasarca)

decision_rules.rule_description: Dose modification for neurologic toxicity greater than Grade 2.

conditions.description: Confusion or mood alteration > Grade 2.

actions.action_description: Hold dexamethasone until symptoms resolve.
Restart at 1 dose decrement. If symptoms persist, decrease by another level or discontinue permanently.

provenance.text_snippet: Hold dexamethasone until symptoms resolve. Restart at 1 dose decrement. If symptoms persist despite above measures, decrease by another level or discontinue dexamethasone permanently.
Neurology Confusion or mood alteration > Grade 2 (interfering with function ± interfering with activities of daily living)

decision_rules.rule_description: Dose reduction for muscle weakness greater than Grade 2.

conditions.description: Muscle weakness > Grade 2.

actions.action_description: Decrease dexamethasone by 1 dose level. If weakness persists, decrease by 1 more dose level. Discontinue permanently if symptoms persist.

provenance.text_snippet: Decrease dexamethasone by 1 dose level. If weakness persists, decrease dose by 1 more dose level. Discontinue dexamethasone permanently if symptoms persist.
Musculoskeletal Muscle weakness > Grade 2 (symptomatic and interfering with function ± interfering with activities of daily living)

decision_rules.rule_description: Dose reduction for uncontrolled Grade 3 or higher hyperglycemia.

conditions.description: Hyperglycemia ≥ Grade 3 that is uncontrolled despite supportive measures.

actions.action_description: Treatment with insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents as needed.
If uncontrolled, decrease dose by 1 dose level until levels are satisfactory.

provenance.text_snippet: Treatment with insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents as needed. If uncontrolled despite above measures, decrease dose by 1 dose level until levels are satisfactory.
Metabolic Hyperglycemia ≥ Grade 3

_agentDocumentation.purpose:
Extracts actionable safety decision rules including dose modification triggers,
    study stopping rules, and organ-specific adjustments. These translate directly
    into EDC edit checks and medical monitor alert configurations.
_agentDocumentation.scope:
- Safety parameter categories discovered in protocol
    - Decision points with conditions and actions
    - Dose modification levels (reduction percentages, absolute doses)
    - Re-escalation criteria
    - Study stopping rules (individual and aggregate)
    - Organ-specific dose adjustments (hepatic, renal, cardiac)
    - Recovery/rechallenge criteria

keyInsights.name: Dose Reduction Levels
keyInsights.description: Defined dose levels (-1, -2, etc.) with absolute or percentage reductions

automationRules.description: Configure allowed dose levels in IRT
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH level IN dose_modification_levels.levels:
                        CREATE irt_dose_option {
                            level_id: level.level_name,
                            dose_value: level.absolute_dose OR (starting_dose * level.percentage/100),
                            kit_assignment: DERIVE_KIT(dose_value)
                        }
                    SET allowed_transitions = DEFINE_REDUCTION_PATH(levels)
automationRules.example: Level -1 = 300mg, Level -2 = 200mg, discontinue if further reduction needed

keyInsights.name: Decision Rules
keyInsights.description: If-then rules mapping safety findings to required actions

automationRules.description: Generate edit checks from decision rules
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH rule IN decision_rules:
                        CREATE edit_check {
                            trigger: PARSE_CONDITION(rule.condition),
                            action: rule.action,
                            message: 'Protocol requires: ' + rule.action + ' when ' + rule.condition,
                            severity: IF rule.action CONTAINS 'discontinue' THEN 'hard' ELSE 'soft'
                        }
automationRules.example: IF ALT > 5x ULN THEN 'Hold study drug, notify medical monitor'

automationRules.description: Configure real-time safety alerts from decision rules
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH rule WHERE rule.notify IS NOT NULL:
                        CREATE alert {
                            condition: rule.condition,
                            recipients: rule.notify,
                            urgency: DERIVE_URGENCY(rule.action),
                            include_data: [rule.parameter, subject_id, site_id]
                        }

keyInsights.name: Stopping Rules
keyInsights.description: Individual and study-level stopping conditions

automationRules.description: Configure enrollment stops based on stopping rules
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH stop_rule WHERE stop_rule.scope == 'study':
                        CREATE enrollment_hold_trigger {
                            condition: stop_rule.condition,
                            action: 'PAUSE_ENROLLMENT',
                            notify: ['sponsor', 'dsmb', 'irb'],
                            resume_requires: 'sponsor_authorization'
                        }

keyInsights.name: Organ-Specific Adjustments
keyInsights.description: Hepatic, renal, cardiac, hematologic dose adjustments

automationRules.description: Generate lab-triggered dose recommendations
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH adjustment:
                        CREATE lab_alert {
                            lab_test: adjustment.lab_parameter,
                            thresholds: adjustment.thresholds,
                            actions: adjustment.actions,
                            display_message: FORMAT_RECOMMENDATION(adjustment)
                        }
automationRules.example: CrCl 30-50 mL/min → Reduce to 75% of dose

automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH rule IN decision_rules:
                        CREATE edit_check {
                            trigger: PARSE_CONDITION(rule.condition),
                            action: rule.action,
                            message: 'Protocol requires: ' + rule.action + ' when ' + rule.condition,
                            severity: IF rule.action CONTAINS 'discontinue' THEN 'hard' ELSE 'soft'
                        }
automationRules.example: IF ALT > 5x ULN THEN 'Hold study drug, notify medical monitor'

automationRules.description: Configure real-time safety alerts from decision rules
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH rule WHERE rule.notify IS NOT NULL:
                        CREATE alert {
                            condition: rule.condition,
                            recipients: rule.notify,
                            urgency: DERIVE_URGENCY(rule.action),
                            include_data: [rule.parameter, subject_id, site_id]
                        }

automationRules.description: Configure enrollment stops based on stopping rules
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH stop_rule WHERE stop_rule.scope == 'study':
                        CREATE enrollment_hold_trigger {
                            condition: stop_rule.condition,
                            action: 'PAUSE_ENROLLMENT',
                            notify: ['sponsor', 'dsmb', 'irb'],
                            resume_requires: 'sponsor_authorization'
                        }

automationRules.description: Generate lab-triggered dose recommendations
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH adjustment:
                        CREATE lab_alert {
                            lab_test: adjustment.lab_parameter,
                            thresholds: adjustment.thresholds,
                            actions: adjustment.actions,
                            display_message: FORMAT_RECOMMENDATION(adjustment)
                        }
automationRules.example: CrCl 30-50 mL/min → Reduce to 75% of dose

prohibited_medications.prohibition_reason_detail: Prohibited to avoid confounding efficacy assessment. Only bortezomib, dexamethasone, and venetoclax/placebo are permitted.

provenance.text_snippet: Any systemic anti-myeloma therapies other than bortezomib, dexamethasone and venetoclax while on study treatment.

provenance.text_snippet: Biologic agents (e.g., monoclonal antibodies) for anti-neoplastic intent.

conditions.timing_restriction: Systemic corticosteroids > 10 mg/day prednisone equivalent should not be given on the same day as dexamethasone.
conditions.clinical_scenario: Allowed for reasons other than multiple myeloma (e.g., asthma). Doses >10mg/day are allowed only if dexamethasone is not interrupted, duration is <7 days, and cumulative dose is <120mg.

restricted_medications.rationale: To minimize confounding effects on efficacy and safety assessments.

provenance.text_snippet: Only low dose corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone ≤ 10 mg PO QD or its equivalent), inhaled steroids and topical preparations for reasons other than multiple myeloma (e.g., asthma) are allowed during study treatment. Systemic corticosteroids > 10 mg PO QD of prednisone (or its equivalent) should not be given on the same day as dexamethasone is administered.

conditions.monitoring_requirements: Closely monitor the international normalized ratio (INR).

Aliskiren, ambrisentan, colchicine, dabigatran etexilate, digoxin, everolimus,* fexofenadine, lapatinib,* loperamide, maraviroc, nilotinib,* ranolazine, saxagliptin, sirolimus,* sitagliptin, talinolol, tolvaptan, topotecan*

timing.timing_description: Must be administered for the first 90 days on study and when Grade 4 neutropenia develops, continuing until ANC > 500 cells/µL.

provenance.text_snippet: Additionally, Levofloxacin (500 mg daily, adjusted for renal function as necessary) or equivalent antibiotic therapy per institutional guidelines must be administered for the first 90 days on study and when Grade 4 neutropenia develops (ANC < 500 cells/µL) and continued until the neutropenia improves to Grade 3 or better (ANC > 500 cells/µL).

timing.timing_description: Consider in all subjects at least 72 hours prior to the first day of dosing.

required_medications.purpose: Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS) prophylaxis for subjects with high uric acid levels.

drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Increases venetoclax concentration, potentially increasing toxicity.
drug_interactions.management_detail: Reduce the venetoclax dose by 4-fold during co-administration. Monitor closely for toxicities. After discontinuation of inhibitor, wait 3 days before increasing venetoclax dose.

provenance.text_snippet:
Strong and Moderate CYP3A inhibitors
Consider alternative medications. If subject requires use of these medications, use with caution and reduce the venetoclax dose by 2-fold for moderate inhibitors and 4-fold for strong inhibitors during co-administration. Patients should be monitored more closely for signs of toxicities and the dose may need to be further adjusted.
After discontinuation of CYP3A inhibitor, wait for 3 days before venetoclax dose is increased back to the previous dose level.

specific_restrictions: Live attenuated vaccines are not allowed while on study treatment.

provenance.text_snippet: All subjects must be vaccinated against pneumococcus and receive a yearly influenza vaccination (live attenuated vaccines are not allowed), while on study treatment... herbal_supplements_policy.rationale: St. John's Wort is a strong CYP3A inducer. Grapefruit, Seville oranges, and starfruit are CYP3A inhibitors.

provenance.text_snippet: Subjects may not consume the following: grapefruit or grapefruit products, Seville oranges (including marmalade containing Seville oranges) or starfruit within the 3-day period prior to the first study treatment administration and until the last day of treatment is completed due to possible CYP3A mediated metabolic interaction.

5.2.4 Prior and Concomitant Therapy
Any medication or vaccine (including over-the-counter or prescription medications, vitamins and/or herbal supplements) that the subject is receiving at the time of enrollment, or receives during the study, must be documented in source documents and electronic case report forms (eCRFs) along with the reason for use, date(s) of administration including start and end dates, and dosage information including dose, route, and frequency.

_agentDocumentation.purpose:
Extracts medication restrictions, drug interactions, washout requirements, and required
    premedications. Essential for site guidance, eligibility verification, and drug
    interaction checking in EDC.
_agentDocumentation.scope:
- Prohibited medications (with reasons and periods)
    - Restricted medications (with conditions for use)
    - Required premedications and prophylaxis
    - Rescue medications
    - Washout requirements
    - Drug-drug interactions (CYP450, QT, etc.)
    - Vaccine policy
    - Herbal/supplement restrictions

keyInsights.name: Prohibited Medications
keyInsights.description: Completely banned drug classes with prohibition reasons and periods

automationRules.description: Alert when prohibited medication is entered
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH cm_entry:
                        IF cm_entry.drug_class IN prohibited_medications[].medication_class THEN:
                            IF cm_entry.dates OVERLAP study_period THEN
                                RAISE 'Prohibited medication during study period'
                            SET protocol_deviation = TRUE
automationRules.example: Strong CYP3A4 inhibitor during treatment → Protocol deviation query

keyInsights.name: Washout Requirements
keyInsights.description: Required washout periods before study entry

automationRules.description: Validate washout period for prior medications
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH prior_med:
                        washout = LOOKUP(prior_med.drug_class, washout_requirements)
                        IF prior_med.end_date + washout.duration_days > first_dose_date THEN
                            RAISE 'Insufficient washout period for ' + prior_med.drug_class
automationRules.example: Prior chemotherapy end date + 28 days must be before first dose

keyInsights.name: Drug Interactions
keyInsights.description: CYP450 inhibitors/inducers, QT prolonging agents with management

automationRules.description: Real-time drug interaction checking
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH new_cm:
                        interactions = MATCH(new_cm, drug_interactions[].affected_drugs)
                        IF interactions.length > 0 THEN:
                            DISPLAY interaction_warning(interactions)
                            IF interaction.severity == 'strong' THEN NOTIFY medical_monitor

keyInsights.name: Required Premedications
keyInsights.description: Mandatory premedications with dosing and timing

automationRules.description: Verify required premedications were administered
automationRules.ruleLogic:
FOR EACH treatment_visit:
                        required_premeds = FILTER(required_medications, type='premedication')
                        FOR EACH premed IN required_premeds:
                            IF NOT premed_administered(premed) THEN
                                RAISE 'Required premedication not documented: ' + premed.name
automationRules.example: Diphenhydramine 50mg IV required 30 min before infusion

discovered_specimen_types.purpose_description: To avoid ex vivo uric acid degradation from rasburicase

provenance.text_snippet:
a. For samples analyzed locally, at room temperature, rasburicase causes enzymatic degradation of the uric acid in blood/plasma/serum samples potentially resulting in spuriously low plasma uric acid readings. The following special sample handling procedure must be followed to avoid ex vivo uric acid degradation.
1. Uric acid must be analyzed in plasma.
